channel.title: Portfolio Webste for Oriana Wei
channel.description: Recent content on Portfolio Webste for Oriana Wei

item.title: Climate Change and Temperature Anomalies Analysis
item.description: To study climate change, we have used data on the Combined Land-Surface Air and Sea-Surface Water Temperature Anomalies in the Northern Hemisphere from NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies. The base period to calculate changes is taken as 1951-1980.While loading the data, skip and na are used to remove the first row and missing values respectively: weather <- read_csv("https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/tabledata_v3/NH.Ts+dSST.csv", skip = 1, na = "***") Let’s have a look on the dataset we have first:

item.title: Trump's Approval Margins Analysis
item.description: We got detailed data from fivethirtyeight.com all polls that track the president’s approval to analyse Trump’s approval margins. # or directly off fivethirtyeight website approval_polllist <- read_csv('https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-data/approval_polllist.csv') Let’s have a look on the dataset first: glimpse(approval_polllist) ## Rows: 15,487 ## Columns: 22 ## $ president <chr> "Donald Trump", "Donald Trump", "Donald Trump", "… ## $ subgroup <chr> "All polls", "All polls", "All polls", "All polls… ## $ modeldate <chr> "9/15/2020", "9/15/2020", "9/15/2020", "9/15/2020… ## $ startdate <chr> "1/20/2017", "1/20/2017", "1/21/2017", "1/20/2017… ## $ enddate <chr> "1/22/2017", "1/22/2017", "1/23/2017", "1/24/2017… ## $ pollster <chr> "Gallup", "Morning Consult", "Gallup", "Ipsos", "… ## $ grade <chr> "B", "B/C", "B", "B-", "B+", "B", "C+", "B-", "B"… ## $ samplesize <dbl> 1500, 1992, 1500, 1632, 1190, 1500, 1500, 1651, 1… ## $ population <chr> "a", "rv", "a", "a", "rv", "a", "lv", "a", "a", "… ## $ weight <dbl> 0.

item.title: Beer Consuming
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set( message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, tidy=FALSE, # display code as typed size="small") # slightly smaller font for code options(digits = 3) # default figure size knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width=6.75, fig.height=6.75, fig.align = "center" ) The aim of the first task is to study the data taken from fivethiryeight.com about the alcohol consumption in different countries. library(fivethirtyeight) data(drinks) Let’s first have a quick look at the variables present in this data:

item.title: Bike Sharing Rentals Analysis
item.description: We got the latest TfL data on how many bikes were hired every single day to analyse the rentals: url <- "https://data.london.gov.uk/download/number-bicycle-hires/ac29363e-e0cb-47cc-a97a-e216d900a6b0/tfl-daily-cycle-hires.xlsx" # Download TFL data to temporary file httr::GET(url, write_disk(bike.temp <- tempfile(fileext = ".xlsx"))) ## Response [https://airdrive-secure.s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/london/dataset/number-bicycle-hires/2020-08-26T09%3A19%3A21/tfl-daily-cycle-hires.xlsx?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIAJJDIMAIVZJDICKHA%2F20200916%2Feu-west-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20200916T074228Z&X-Amz-Expires=300&X-Amz-Signature=11719254f02cadca7c5dc4cc514195a682d16b1c01cc392a27480a06a1101c81&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host] ## Date: 2020-09-16 07:46 ## Status: 200 ## Content-Type: application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet ## Size: 164 kB ## <ON DISK> /var/folders/sy/j0yjcqzn57n43076k22vm9040000gn/T//Rtmpr3yRH3/filee1507e0435dd.xlsx # Use read_excel to read it as dataframe bike0 <- read_excel(bike.temp, sheet = "Data", range = cell_cols("A:B")) # change dates to get year, month, and week bike <- bike0 %>% clean_names() %>% rename (bikes_hired = number_of_bicycle_hires) %>% mutate (year = year(day), month = lubridate::month(day, label = TRUE), week = isoweek(day)) When we look at May and Jun and compare 2020 with the previous years, we can clearly see the decrease in bike rentals for 2020.

item.title: COVID-19 Death Rate Analysis
item.description: COVID-19 affects different people in different ways. Most infected people will develop mild to moderate illness and recover without hospitalization. We use CDC Covid-19 Case Surveillance Data to extract some insights on COVID death rate. # URL link to CDC to download data url <- "https://data.cdc.gov/api/views/vbim-akqf/rows.csv?accessType=DOWNLOAD" covid_data <- vroom(url)%>% clean_names() Let’s skim the data to find out the variables, unique values and missing values first: skim(covid_data) Table 1: Data summary Name covid_data Number of rows 3662325 Number of columns 11 _______________________ Column type frequency: character 8 Date 3 ________________________ Group variables None Variable type: character

item.title: HPAIR 2019
item.description: People may not remember your name, you face or your experience but they will always remember how you make them feel. What makes me love Boston so much? The people I met here!

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
